Speaker: voice
Dialogue: Wow. That's hard. I'd have to say it's the day we launched Outpost

Dialogue: It bums me out when the media say we're cultish, or whatever. Why? 'Cause we care about each other?

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: 'Love you too, bro.

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: How Gary gets this superbad rap.

Speaker: gary
Dialogue: A kid working in his garage can create the next Outpost, the new IBM. All it takes is a great idea.

Speaker: gary
Dialogue: That's why nobody can have a monopoly in a business built on ideas.

Speaker: larry
Dialogue: Can we go?

Speaker: larry
Dialogue: 'Starting to get nauseated.

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: Do you mind?

Speaker: alice
Dialogue: Is it over?

Speaker: larry
Dialogue: They still have to give 'em refreshments laced with mind-altering drugs.

Speaker: alice
Dialogue: You are a fanatic.

Speaker: larry
Dialogue: 'Gonna wait outside.

Speaker: alice
Dialogue: "Make" him?

Speaker: larry
Dialogue: You know what I mean.

Speaker: larry
Dialogue: I'm just screwed.

Speaker: alice
Dialogue: You know what he's like. He just wants to work on stuff that's cool.

Speaker: larry
Dialogue: You don't wanna move, do you?

Speaker: alice
Dialogue: I can paint anywhere.

Speaker: alice
Dialogue: I'd like to stay here, yeah. And I kind of think he should be with Teddy.

Speaker: alice
Dialogue: Maybe you shouldn't push it so hard. About Outpost. No offense, you sound insane.

Speaker: larry
Dialogue: I can't help it. I feel like they'd do anything to keep their --

Speaker: alice
Dialogue: Anything? That's not even credible. If he wants to go up there? To check it out? I think you should encourage him.  It's his life. But everybody's treating him like this -- valuable object. You're hurting your own case.

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: He's my god. I hear he actually calls recruits sometimes. Or is that an Urban Legend?

Speaker: redmond
Dialogue: Gary's running the biggest software company in the world, Brian. He's being harassed by the Justice Department, and he's got a new baby.

Speaker: danny
Dialogue: Milo? I'm Danny.

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: Oh hi.

Speaker: danny
Dialogue: Gary would like to speak to you?

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: ...Hello?

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: You would? Wow. When would we come?  'Think he hung up.

Speaker: alice
Dialogue: But how does he know that's what you guys're working on?

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: All the companies know. The faculties tell 'em. At the target schools.

Speaker: larry
Dialogue: In exchange for endowments. They should just drop the pretense and name the schools after 'em.

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: I can't believe you refused a ticket!

Speaker: teddy
Dialogue: My parents're already freaked-out I'm staying here. 50 miles from Chinatown.

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: Well maybe if you told 'em how much money you'd be making --  You're going up there. Right?

Speaker: larry
Dialogue: I think you should go.

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: You do?

Speaker: larry
Dialogue: I mean, it's your life.

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: I think I kind of lost it. I was just so thrilled to be talking to the richest, most powerful... 'Didn't know I even cared about that stuff.

Speaker: alice
Dialogue: C'mon, how often do you talk to somebody who's been on the cover of Time. Three of four times.

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: A lot of what Larry says is true. They just clone stuff, or reverse engineer it, and everybody gets stuck with their inferior version cause they --

Speaker: alice
Dialogue: Then you've gotta ask him about that.

Speaker: alice
Dialogue: It's important.

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: If he's really a bully, he won't cop to it, anyway.

Speaker: alice
Dialogue: Bully? Are we talking about Gary Boyd? Or your dad.

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: When I was a kid? And he was moving us all over the place? I spent all my time writing stuff on Outpost 1.0. I thought Gary Boyd was the greatest.

Speaker: alice
Dialogue: But he's not quite the same guy anymore. Don't get your hopes too high?

Speaker: danny
Dialogue: 'Couldn't convince Teddy to come?

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: He's pretty tight with his family.

Speaker: danny
Dialogue: We could move 'em up here.

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: He just likes to write code. He's bummed there's so much secrecy and competition, everybody trying to own everything.

Speaker: redmond
Dialogue: Who do you mean by "everybody."

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: So -- how far are we from the campus?

Speaker: redmond
Dialogue: Oh we're not going to the campus.

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: Who's that?

Speaker: danny
Dialogue: I think they call him the "Houseman." 'Cause "guard" sounds too weird.

Speaker: danny
Dialogue: Don't be nervous. The house is the weirdest thing about him.

Speaker: redmond
Dialogue: It's like he knows everybody expects him to be this worldly, colorful zillionaire. But he's just a guy who likes software.

Speaker: houseman
Dialogue: Have a seat. He won't be long.

Speaker: phil
Dialogue: We tried the big vaporware number, Gary, it's no-sale.

Speaker: randy
Dialogue: Can we buy into their IPO? Or is that a Justice Dept. problem?

Speaker: phil
Dialogue: There is no public offering. The guy who wrote it joined some freakazoid cult in San Luis Obispo. 'Wrote this just to run their web site.

Speaker: gary
Dialogue: Milo? Excuse the tie. I was on TV.

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: ...That's okay.

Speaker: gary
Dialogue: The house knows the paintings I like, it knows my favorite music. Same for anybody else who's in the system.

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: Cool!

Speaker: gary
Dialogue: Would you like a Coke or something?

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: Oh. No thanks.

Speaker: gary
Dialogue: When we started, I just hired my smart friends. That was great. We got a little bigger, I had to hire smart strangers. Much harder.

Speaker: gary
Dialogue: Now I don't get to hire anybody. But I know you're the guy to write Skywire.

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: You know a lot about art, I guess.

Speaker: gary
Dialogue: There's a rumor going around, maybe you've heard it.

Speaker: gary
Dialogue: There's more to life than computers? I'm looking into it.

Speaker: gary
Dialogue: 'Once I start looking into something.

Speaker: gary
Dialogue: I've only shown this to three other people. I bought 200, we've launched 12 so far. I keep the coordinates in this room.  It's left over from SDI. Reagan's Star Wars technology? They orbit 426 miles up.

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: Low enough to relay internet traffic.

Speaker: gary
Dialogue: Among other things... We know convergence is the real super-highway: all the PC's, TV's, phones, etc. linked together. Why cram it into a cable if you can use the whole sky?

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: Skywire.

Speaker: gary
Dialogue: The content filer has t'be written into the media files so bits coming off the satellite can be read by multiplatforms. Really, omniplatforms. Including whatever new hardware emerges.

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: It needs a more object-oriented language. This doesn't scale, does it?

Speaker: gary
Dialogue: You'd have to start practically from scratch. But this is all you'd be working on. No marketing meetings, no product seminars. We can't waste the time. Half the Valley's working on convergence. So're media conglomerates, cable companies, phone companies. 'Can't finish second, Milo. There is no second... Now what would you like to ask me?

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: ...Ask you?

Speaker: gary
Dialogue: I know what people say, and not just the Justice Department. We clone ideas, inflict our second-rate versions on the world, we haven't

Speaker: gary
Dialogue: Do I think that's fair? No. I'd put some of our apps up against anybody's. But is there some truth to it?

Speaker: gary
Dialogue: When you get to a certain age, you start wondering. About your legacy. I doubt you even remember Outpost

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: I do!

Speaker: gary
Dialogue: But somehow got away.

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: If my dad'd leveled with me like that even once... The weird thing is, my fantasy he could somehow be like the old Gary? It's his fantasy, too.

Speaker: alice
Dialogue: I think that's great, Milo. I do.

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: ...But?

Speaker: alice
Dialogue: Didn't you visit the campus?

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: I forgot. That's why you have to help me decide.

Speaker: alice
Dialogue: No way. You have this -- destiny.

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: C'mon, I wouldn't have a destiny without you. My destiny would be

Speaker: alice
Dialogue: Don't bring that up. Like a different girlfriend would'd've let you die?

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: You saved my life in alot of ways.

Speaker: alice
Dialogue: It's not just Gary that makes you wanna go there? 'Cause it's a big place. You might not even see him again.

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: I know.

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: When's Brian coming for the TV?

Speaker: alice
Dialogue: Prob'ly waiting by the phone for Outpost to call. We'll leave it for him?

Speaker: alice
Dialogue: 'Give you guys some time alone.

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: ...You got my E-mail?

Speaker: teddy
Dialogue: And your phone messages. You wanna do what you do, it's not a crime.

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: Is that how Larry feels?

Speaker: teddy
Dialogue: Uh. Not exactly.

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: Wanted to say goodbye to him...

Speaker: teddy
Dialogue: Hey, we got seed money for the startup! A million-five!

Speaker: teddy
Dialogue: We rented a loft in Sunnyvale.  You know what's the bad part? We can't talk about work anymore. We're competitors! The venture capitalists made us sign like 100 confidentiality forms.

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: Outpost made me sign 1,000. 'Guess we'll find out what else we have to talk about. Life stuff.

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: Guess what? They got their --

Speaker: alice
Dialogue: Milo, this is Mr. Barton from the Justice Department.  Sorry about the glass.

Speaker: barton
Dialogue: Don't worry, Milo. I'm here as a friend. Or maybe a supplicant.

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: Right... What's that mean again?

Speaker: barton
Dialogue: Beggar. We're at a disadvantage with Outpost. Our experts aren't as smart as theirs. Sometimes we can't tell which technologies pose the threat of a monopoly. We need a really smart guy to help us pick our fights. I'm taking a shot in the dark, here. I can offer you 32,000 a year, a Buick. I'm hoping you've got a feeling it's the right thing to do.

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: It's just -- I kind of feel the need to do something with my ability. Create something...

Speaker: barton
Dialogue: Like I said: shot in the dark.

Speaker: barton
Dialogue: If you see something there that rubs you the wrong way? Do the right thing.

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: That took some fun out of --

Speaker: alice
Dialogue: We're not gonna let it.

Speaker: cnn voice

Dialogue: There're 20 buildings, I mean not counting the Gyms, the Day Care, etc.

Dialogue: Gary's put millions in there. And the people with kids? They're not hotshot geeks, they're just payroll clerks or whatever.

Dialogue: You'll see alot of that: Department of Justice goons snooping around.

Dialogue: So how'd you like the house?

Dialogue: 'Guess he needs to micro-manage something.

Speaker: redmond
Dialogue: Desi, Milo.

Dialogue: The guy who was at Gary's house?

Dialogue: Best bomb shelters in America, accessible from every building. You gotta figure we're a major target, right?

Speaker: redmond
Dialogue: Whoa. Lisa actually looked at you.

Speaker: redmond
Dialogue: Every geek here's got a thing for Lisa. But that's about the biggest reaction she's had to anybody.

Dialogue: She's a programmer?

Speaker: redmond
Dialogue: Heavy graphical background, doing design-interface for Skywire apps.  You'll be working with her.

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: I've got a girlfriend, remember?

Speaker: redmond
Dialogue: Right. That's rare around here. You know how nuns' re-married to Jesus? 'Posties are married to Outpost.

Speaker: redmond
Dialogue: Here's your world.  Copy of Gary's book, also the audio version, narrated by Gary.

Speaker: shrot
Dialogue: If you see a tailgater, report him.

Dialogue: Tailgater?

Dialogue: You see somebody wandering around without ID, it's your duty to challenge him. I don't give a shit if you're a stock-option billionaire. If you don't challenge, I'll have your butt.

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: He seems a little -- tense.

Speaker: redmond
Dialogue: Geeks pull his chain cause he's non- tech. Ex-cop or something. They moon cameras, or use ATM's as swipe cards. The cameras're our real security so he's a little demoralized.

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: What're they building?

Speaker: redmond
Dialogue: #21. Way behind schedule. It's top- secret, but everybody knows it's a digital broadcast space. They see the dishes on top, the fiber optics going in.

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: Gary's not into fiber optics. He's betting everything on the satellites.

Speaker: redmond
Dialogue: You wanna survive in the software business, you cover your bets... I gotta say, this is the weirdest car anybody ever requested.

Speaker: redmond
Dialogue: Oh, right. Your girlfriend's an artist.

Speaker: redmond
Dialogue: I phoned her at your hotel, told her about our corporate housing options. She sounds neat.

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: ...She is.  She is!

Speaker: redmond
Dialogue: 'Might be some friction on the domestic front. You're expected you to put in ridiculous hours. People've accused us of breaking up relationships to get their undivided attention.

Speaker: redmond
Dialogue: Your counselor'll fill you in on everything else. That's who you'll be working with almost daily.

Speaker: voice
Dialogue: Busy?

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: No! Just waiting for my counselor to come by and introduce himself.

Speaker: gary
Dialogue: Okay. I'm Gary.

Speaker: gary
Dialogue: 'Think I should buy some originals?

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: ...Do I?

Speaker: gary
Dialogue: Somebody said I'm just another Philistine. With reproductions.

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: That's insane. You're ahead of your time.

Speaker: gary
Dialogue: That's what I told her. My wife.

Speaker: gary
Dialogue: 'Thinks I'll be less of a control freak if I have a hobby. 'Just gives me something else to obsess about...

Speaker: gary
Dialogue: Anything we can salvage from the old code before you start fresh?

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: Uh, might be one or two things.

Speaker: geek 1
Dialogue: He's been in there like an hour.

Speaker: geek 2
Dialogue: Shit.

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: Could work with a new switch. There may be a few more things hidden.

Speaker: gary
Dialogue: Don't spend too much time searching. You ever vetted somebody's old code before?  In a tree.

Speaker: alice
Dialogue: ...The corporate condos were as romantic as they sound.

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: You know he's never been anybody's counselor before?

Speaker: alice
Dialogue: Milo! What about --?

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: Oh, It's great. It's great!  'Think I should tell him I learned everything using 1.0? Maybe I could show him one of my early programs.

Speaker: gary
Dialogue: I don't remember.

Speaker: doj agent
Dialogue: What d'you think you meant by it?

Speaker: gary
Dialogue: I'm confused. Am I supposed to speculate under oath?

Speaker: other agent
Dialogue: Since you didn't have an answer to that question, Mr. Boyd --

Speaker: gary
Dialogue: Didn't I? Have an answer? "I don't remember."

Speaker: doj agent
Dialogue: Did you wanna take a break, Mr. Boyd?

Speaker: phil
Dialogue: Your protege's moving so fast we can barely keep up with him.

Speaker: gary
Dialogue: This is good. Who did it?

Speaker: phil
Dialogue: 'Start-up not 50 miles from here. Kid's on Prozac.

Speaker: gary
Dialogue: Maybe we should all get on it.

Speaker: gary
Dialogue: How's it going?

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: Maybe I'm going too fast.

Speaker: gary
Dialogue: Too fast? At least four companies're on the verge of workable convergence systems, Milo, they --

Speaker: gary
Dialogue: Even when I had a hand in every aspect of the company I knew the one thing you can never control is somebody's creative process.

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: It's okay. Really.

Speaker: gary
Dialogue: Take a look at this. Slightly different approach.

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: You did this -- overnight?

Speaker: gary
Dialogue: You're making me young again.

Speaker: news voice
Dialogue: ...A graduate of MIT, he was on the antidepressant Prozac, and had been warned not to drink and drive.

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: Milo?

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: Lisa.

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: You know my name.

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: You know mine.

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: You're famous around here.

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: I'm getting a teacher's pet rep.

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: I wouldn't worry about it. You've gotta figure most people around here were their teachers' pets.

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: ...Were you?

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: We moved around so much I barely knew my teachers.

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: Me too! Were you an Army brat or something?

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: ...Something like that. Yeah.

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: Didn't mean to pry. I just have this theory. Some of us who got to good at this? We were -- escaping something.

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: Did I say something?

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: No, I know what you mean. I used to spend my life wishing people could be like computers. Least they make sense. Sometimes you think they've betrayed you. Like a person would. But then you see, no, you just missed a step. You can go back and make it all work.

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: I used to wish that. All the time.

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: What've you got there?

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: Graphical interfaces. For Skywire? I'm s'posed to coordinate with you.

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: Show me.

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: Cool!

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: Yeah? I ran it for lots of platforms, ranging from the narrowest bandwidth to --

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: ...Sh-Show me the next one.

Speaker: secretary
Dialogue: Have a seat. He's with someone, but I know he wants to see you.

Speaker: lawyer
Dialogue: Because we bundled it, the judge is threatening to enjoin the whole --

Speaker: gary
Dialogue: I'm confused, Ted.

Speaker: gary
Dialogue: Didn't you tell me they'd be Chapter 12 by the time they could hope to enjoin? I'm very confused, because you said they'd be ready to settle.

Speaker: secretary
Dialogue: Go on in.  He's always happy to see you.

Speaker: gary
Dialogue: Milo. What's up?

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: Well -- you sent for me.

Speaker: gary
Dialogue: Right... Right.

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: You really wrote this just today?

Speaker: gary
Dialogue: What're you implying.

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: Nothing!

Speaker: gary
Dialogue: Everything I do is under scrutiny. The questions they ask, trying to make anything strategic look sordid.  I'm confused. Doesn't everybody in business try to get ahead?

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: I'm sure.

Speaker: gary
Dialogue: The purpose of this company isn't to destroy our competitors any more than the purpose of living is to breath. But the software business is binary: you're a zero or a one. Being obsessive isn't a crime. It's a character trait.

Speaker: gary
Dialogue: It scales, don't you think?

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: Definitely.

Speaker: alice
Dialogue: This feels fairly grown up, I'd say.

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: To our new life.  ...What's wrong?

Speaker: alice
Dialogue: That's what I need to ask you.  You know you can't keep anything from me.

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: He gave me some new code-fixes this morning. I said, "Did you really do this just today?" Cause I was impressed. He said "What're you implying?"

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: It's the way he said it. Just the way my dad did, when he was caught in a lie. That's how you knew you were onto something ugly.

Speaker: alice
Dialogue: What would it mean, anyway? If he didn't write it?

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: That's what I'm asking myself. Does he have some genius stowed away? Why not let him write Skywire.  'Not saying it makes sense.

Speaker: alice
Dialogue: Milo!

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: I'm so stupid.

Speaker: alice
Dialogue: He's your boss. He's not your --

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: I know, I know.

Speaker: alice
Dialogue: If you can't deal with him on that basis, you better get a new counselor.

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: Isn't that -- extreme?

Speaker: alice
Dialogue: What's extreme is what that ER doctor said when he pumped your stomach. Eat another sesame seed and that's it.

Speaker: alice
Dialogue: I mean, if one little comment from Gary is gonna upset you this much --

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: You're right. It's -- a working relationship. Don't know what I was expecting.

Speaker: alice
Dialogue: C'mon. Let's do the toast?

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: Did you wanna be alone?

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: No. Please.

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: They just pushed up the schedule on Skywire apps. How fast are you going?

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: "There is no second place." Plus every time I get jammed-up, Gary has an inspiration.  Is it like that with your counselor?

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: Mine's not the CEO. He barely remembers to take a shower.

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: Right, right. But does he ever just, like, hand you code?

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: Maybe once. I re-wrote it, anyway.

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: You're compulsive.

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: Mmm-more like -- I have a little trouble. Trusting people.

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: Why's that?

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: Long story. Not that interesting.

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: So, when you were talking about wishing people were more like computers. Was that then? Or now?

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: Then and now.  But not right now.

Dialogue: Milo!

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: Just dropped off a resume. Almost got in the front door.

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: You're living here?

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: 'Thought if I relocated it could help my case. I'm writing programs for the local public access station. Where any whack-job with 100 bucks gets his own show? God, does it suck.  Can you help me?

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: Sure, I'll see what I can do.

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: Well I parked illegally. See y'later?

Dialogue: I have a girlfriend.

Dialogue: That's great. I -- didn't know.

Dialogue: She saved my life.

Dialogue: What?!

Dialogue: They're in the neighborhood. They usually hassle Vietnamese grocers.

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: Jesus, Teddy.

Speaker: teddy
Dialogue: I'm cool. They didn't touch the machine. Or my disks. Probably didn't know what they were. So, you a Moonie yet?  Milo?

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: I met this girl.

Dialogue: What? Come on. Is it serious?

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: I don't know.

Speaker: teddy
Dialogue: Did you tell Alice?

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: No! I keep thinking it'll go away. But there's this -- connection. She's been hacking since she was little, she had to move around a lot. Plus I see her every day, we're working on the same program. She's -- beautiful.

Speaker: teddy
Dialogue: A beautiful geek? I don't wanna sound paranoid, or like a pig, but what're the chances?

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: What d'you mean?

Speaker: teddy
Dialogue: I dunno. I guess Larry's got me totally suspicious of that place.

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: What does that mean?

Dialogue: Milo, geeks don't have two girlfriends. Most don't have one.

Dialogue: I didn't plan this.

Dialogue: There may be a little less trust after your outburst.

Dialogue: Hasn't affected his work, though.

Dialogue: Nothing does. Still. I want him to like me.

Dialogue: ...What's wrong?

Dialogue: What!

Dialogue: Teddy was killed last night.

Dialogue: What're you -- what?

Dialogue: It was a hate crime.

Dialogue: I'm sorry. I'm so sorry.

Dialogue: They caught the guys?

Dialogue: It's an airtight case. They found the weapon with Teddy's blood on it and their fingerprints. They'd been arrested twice for beating-up Asians. How come they weren't in jail?

Dialogue: He told me about the break-in. He didn't seem to take it that seriously.

Dialogue: You guys don't take anything seriously do you? That's not on a hard drive?

Dialogue: Nelson? Your mom wants you. It's time to go to scatter the ashes.

Dialogue: I didn't know he was working with fiber optics.

Speaker: alice
Dialogue: We gotta go too, honey.

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: I know you lost all his work. Maybe I could come down here and --

Speaker: larry
Dialogue: You are naive. Look at your employment contract: you can't work anywhere else in this field for at least few years.  Not that I don't miss you.

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: Just thought his work should go on.

Speaker: larry
Dialogue: He was on the verge of something, too. He was gonna show us the next day. He said "The answer's not in the box, it's in the band." Know what it means?

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: It's only meaningful when you've got 40,000 lines of code to back it up.

Speaker: larry
Dialogue: Man, could he write code. Totally elegant. He had his own style.

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: Those really weird, short lines.

Speaker: larry
Dialogue: Take good care of this guy.

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: You okay?

Speaker: gary
Dialogue: I heard what happened.

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: Were the flags for Teddy?

Speaker: gary
Dialogue: Had you talked to him much lately?

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: Just once. 'Guess I was worried we didn't have anything to talk about, since work was off-limits. Non- disclosure.

Speaker: gary
Dialogue: Did you?

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: Talk about work? Never!

Speaker: gary
Dialogue: I meant did you find other stuff to --

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: Oh. Yeah.

Speaker: gary
Dialogue: You've been coming in early.

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: It helps. Alice said it would help. To focus on something.  'Don't know what I'd do without her.

Speaker: alice
Dialogue: You okay?  I miss him, too.

Speaker: gary
Dialogue: Milo?

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: Wow. You must have 20,000 lines of code there...

Speaker: gary
Dialogue: 34,000. But they're real short lines. 'Just came out that way.

Speaker: gary
Dialogue: Been thinking about the push mechanism in the handler. And it came over me: it's in the wrong place.

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: The wrong place?

Speaker: gary
Dialogue: The answer's not in the box. It's in the band.

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: Gotta go home. 'Think I ate something.

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: Alice? Alice!

Speaker: alice
Dialogue: Are you saying you think they had something to do with his death? Nelson said it was an airtight case.

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: I don't know what I'm saying. Maybe -- maybe they hired those guys.

Speaker: alice
Dialogue: I can't see Outpost putting its reputation in the hands of people like that.

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: I don't know! I just know it was Teddy's code. All these ideas flying in from everywhere. You know how he says "Any kid working in his garage can put us out of business?" It's like they know what every kid's doing.

Speaker: alice
Dialogue: They hack into people's programs?

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: Nobody does work like this on-line. It's in your PC, or in a mainframe. Self-contained. They'd have to be, like, watching people. Physically.  Oh Jesus.

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: It's a camera.

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: It isn't a broadcast studio. It's -- a surveillance post or something. That's why they have the dishes on top.

Speaker: alice
Dialogue: You're scaring me. I think we should just go.

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: Go where? You can't get away from people like this.

Speaker: alice
Dialogue: "Like this?" It's Gary you're talking about.

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: You think I don't know that?

Speaker: alice
Dialogue: Milo. Why would he --

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: How should I know? "Solving a problem," I guess. Or needing to control everything. I don't know.  I've gotta get in there.

Speaker: alice
Dialogue: Even if all this were true. There're 20 other buildings. All of them filled with computers and --

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: It's the only one with dishes on the roof. The studio's a front. That's why they keep postponing its opening.  ...gotta get in there.

Speaker: alice
Dialogue: Milo, you told me those DOJ Agents are all over the place. How could they hope to hide a surveillance post?  And how can you get in there, anyway? With the cameras and the swipe cards --

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: I can't just walk away!

Speaker: alice
Dialogue: You can't just walk in, either.

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: They stop the construction work at six or seven. The parking lot's mostly clear by two or three in the morning. Even the early Geeks don't get there before five.

Speaker: alice
Dialogue: Is it two? Or is it three? Have you ever really noticed?

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: No! I can't just keep my head in the sand. That's how I got into this mess.

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: I know how to get in there. But you've gotta help me.

Speaker: alice
Dialogue: ...Whaddo I do?

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: So you believe me?

Speaker: alice
Dialogue: Just tell me what to do.

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: Come on.

Speaker: guard
Dialogue: Sir, you gotta use your own --  Where's your ID?

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: Do you know who I am?

Speaker: guard
Dialogue: It's my job, I gotta --

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: The kind of stock options I'm sitting on?

Speaker: shrot
Dialogue: Every geek has to try this once to show me how smart he is --

Speaker: another guard
Dialogue: There was an explosion in a Y-sector closet, we're evacuating the whole sector.

Speaker: shrot
Dialogue: Un-nh, can't wander around without ID now. Just park your ass in that chair.

Speaker: randy
Dialogue: What is it?

Speaker: shrot
Dialogue: Not much. Glorified cherry bomb. Right by the civil defense sign? Some geek's idea of irony. I been saying we need a camera in this hall.

Speaker: randy
Dialogue: There's nothing in this hall. Someone's pulling your chain, as usual.

Speaker: shrot
Dialogue: Unless it's a diversion. Milo's in my office. He was tailgating, so I --

Speaker: gary
Dialogue: Milo? Try to have a clue. Try to think.

Speaker: randy
Dialogue: That kid's the great white hope.

Speaker: shrot
Dialogue: I could get it out of him.

Speaker: randy
Dialogue: You're not listening.

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: Everything okay?

Speaker: delbert
Dialogue: How's it goin'?

Speaker: guard
Dialogue: Big night. Switched from tea to coffee. Brought new meaning to my work.

Speaker: delbert
Dialogue: Yeah? Maybe I'll start my rounds with #21 tonight.

Speaker: guard
Dialogue: You are a wild man.

Speaker: randy
Dialogue: Maybe he'll get back to work.

Speaker: phil
Dialogue: Speaking of which...

Speaker: randy
Dialogue: Yeah, yeah.

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: ...in a tree...

Speaker: phil
Dialogue: Did you download Corey? In San Jose?

Speaker: randy
Dialogue: Damn. 'Have to go back over there.  Be so much easier if we could walk in the front door.

Speaker: phil
Dialogue: You don't look anything like a three- year-old.

Speaker: multimedia narrator
Dialogue: -- run this methamphetamine lab known to Federal Authorities, per ND 47, from which we removed the implement, fingerprints intact.

Speaker: multimedia narrator
Dialogue: FBI footage, procured by ND 47, shows the aftermath of an Aryan Nations' killing in Denver. Note the evidence of torture, which is typical.

Speaker: multimedia narrator
Dialogue: -- complete immersion in code-writing renders him both unobservant and suggestible [click]. On two occasions he went truant from classes to attend Comix Conventions.

Speaker: multimedia narrator
Dialogue: -- Rebecca P, a Connecticut art stu- dent facing Federal drug charges, whose records were supplied to us by

Speaker: multimedia narrator
Dialogue: ...she planted the sesame seed both to test the extent of his proclivity and to provide a bonding experience, since she would quote "save his life."

Speaker: multimedia narrator
Dialogue: -- should it be needed Milo's allergy is the ideal --

Speaker: multimedia narrator
Dialogue: Note that the cult members are found reclining after swallowing the [click] Syringe marks best hidden at base of scrotum [click] mimics high blood alcohol [click] indistinguishable from kidney failure.

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: Please don't be one of them.

Speaker: multimedia narrator
Dialogue: ...needs to be watched, due to her heightened level of suspicion --

Speaker: multimedia narrator
Dialogue: -- and to her possible contagion of key employees.

Speaker: multimedia narrator
Dialogue: In August '86 Lisa informed her mother of the sexual molestation by her stepfather, and of his threat to kill her should she tell anyone.

Speaker: doj receptionist
Dialogue: He's not in yet.

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: Can I wait in his office?

Speaker: doj receptionist
Dialogue: It's locked, dear.

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: Please.

Speaker: doj receptionist
Dialogue: Wait in his outer office.

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: Mr. Barton, do you remember me?

Speaker: barton
Dialogue: ...It's -- Milo, isn't it?

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: Yes sir. I need to talk to you.

Speaker: barton
Dialogue: Give me two seconds with Lacy here?  Go on in, I won't be a moment.

Speaker: barton
Dialogue: Milo?

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: Yeah. Hi. Thank you for seeing me.

Speaker: barton
Dialogue: Have a seat.

Speaker: barton
Dialogue: What seems to be the problem? You look a little upset.

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: I am. I am, sir.

Speaker: barton
Dialogue: Milo?

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: My friend, my best friend, Teddy, was killed in Silicon Valley.

Speaker: barton
Dialogue: My goodness.

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: It was racially motivated. He's Chinese. He was. And... I know sometimes the FBI gets involved with that. Don't they?

Speaker: barton
Dialogue: If there's a Civil Rights violation. But generally we let the local police and DA do their work first.

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: I -- just wanna help bring these guys to justice. They're neo-Nazis.

Speaker: barton
Dialogue: Let me look into it, see what's being done. Frankly, it's not my area.

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: 'Just didn't know who else to talk to.

Speaker: barton
Dialogue: And Outpost? You're happy there?

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: Yes sir.

Speaker: alice
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: phil
Dialogue: Not like him, is it? To do a thing like that without telling you. You're not losing your hold on him, are you?

Speaker: alice
Dialogue: He'll tell me when he gets home.

Speaker: phil
Dialogue: That'll be a test, won't it?

Speaker: alice
Dialogue: Instead of busting my chops you should do something about that girl. Fire her. Or something.

Speaker: phil
Dialogue: Lisa's an extremely valuable member of the Skywire team. We've got our eyes on her. You keep yours on Milo.

Speaker: alice
Dialogue: Prick.

Speaker: alice
Dialogue: It's almost nine, I've been so worried!  What did you see in there?

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: Nothing.

Speaker: alice
Dialogue: Nothing?

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: It's what they said it is. An unfinished broadcast studio. You were right... I just drove to Seattle and back.

Speaker: alice
Dialogue: ...Why?

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: Remember Lyle Barton?

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: The Justice Department guy who came to the apartment when --

Speaker: alice
Dialogue: I remember.

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: After I broke into 21 -- which was insane, thank God they didn't catch me! -- I just drove around. Trying to figure out what possessed me. You know what? I've been putting my own guilt on Gary.

Speaker: alice
Dialogue: Guilt?

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: If I'd stayed down there, maybe this wouldn't've happened.

Speaker: alice
Dialogue: Poor baby. You know that's not true.

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: I thought, instead of indulging all these paranoid delusions, risking my job, alienating Gary, scaring you, I should do something useful with my grief. Help them find Teddy's killers.

Speaker: alice
Dialogue: I was so worried about you.

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: ...been such a long night.

Speaker: alice
Dialogue: That was -- different.

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: ...Different?

Speaker: alice
Dialogue: You didn't feel it? So intense.

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: So you're not avoiding me.

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: What's wrong?

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: Why would you do a thing like --

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: You thought about it too. You've been suspicious for a while. But it's not happening in there. It's happening in the Day Care.

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: The Day Care?

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: Can we go someplace else?

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: It's easy to know who the smart geeks are, the schools tell 'em. They upload medical files, school records, pharmacy files. They'd be happy just to steal code forever. But when a program gets close to fruition. Like Teddy. He was almost there.

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: But why would they --?

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: You know. There is no second place. And what's the risk? The killings're undetectable, they're hand-tailored, they make "sense." I mean, they're in the information business. They have scenarios for all of us, too. In case we find out too much.

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: I'm not one of them. Not trying to "suss you out."

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: They killed my best friend! I'm living with somebody they pay to go to bed with me. Can't you trust somebody just once? I don't wanna be alone here.

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: I'm sorry, Milo... I'm sorry.

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: I know what he did to you.

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: Oh yeah?

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: So that's in my -- file?

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: Is that my -- scenario?  Tell me.

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: They'd frame him.

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: He's out of prison?

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: They're already watching you. If they had to, they'd give him this drug that mimics an alcoholic blackout. He'd wake up not even remembering his "act of revenge."

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: Nobody's gonna hurt you.

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: ...Milo?

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: Hmm?

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: I always felt if a -- boy I liked ever found out -- he'd run. He'd think I was unclean.

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: No, no. Never.

Speaker: voice
Dialogue: You're sure.

Speaker: alice
Dialogue: He said it made sense that Gary's code was like Teddy's, that that clich about great minds was true. Said it was all about his own guilt.  Plus, he has a tendency to get Gary mixed-up with his dad once in a while. It always passes.

Speaker: phil
Dialogue: He wasn't acting?

Speaker: alice
Dialogue: I don't think he knows how.

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: What about the FBI?

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: They've got this guy in the DOJ, maybe others. We tell the wrong person, it's over.

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: Who can we trust?

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: There's always a logical answer -- you just have to define the question.

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: How do you let go of a secret without telling the wrong person.

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: We don't tell anybody.  We tell everybody. At once. So there's no secret left to protect. When everybody knows, they don't dare touch us.

Speaker: shrot
Dialogue: No, Tony can't fill in for you, he's not at your authorization level.

Speaker: len
Dialogue: Bob? You better look at this.

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: Do we post it on the Net?

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: There're so many disinformation sites about Gary already. Where he has devil's horns or they crop him in with Saddam Hussein.

Speaker: shrot
Dialogue: Could it be a glitch? Something the construction workers caused?

Speaker: len
Dialogue: Unlikely. All 14 cameras are frozen. Do we call Randy and Phil? Tell 'em there may have been a break-in?

Speaker: shrot
Dialogue: Not yet. 'Love to bust my ass cause I'm not in frigging Mensa.  Let's run a printout on card entries.

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: The mainstream media. TV, or a newsmagazine.

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: Right. But Gary's tied-in to a lot of media conglomerates. Have to be careful who we pick.

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: We could cross-reference a data base on media ownership. But not on our own computers. Not even at home.

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: Certainly not at my happy home.

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: Gary, hi.

Speaker: gary
Dialogue: You look a little tired.

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: I'm okay. It's going well!

Speaker: gary
Dialogue: 'Have a look?

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: Sure.

Speaker: gary
Dialogue: Why did you move around so much? When you were a kid.

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: ...My dad was a compulsive gambler. Only he didn't think he was. That applied to guys who didn't have a "system." "Losers," who played games of chance. He could "read" people, so chance had nothing to do with it. No matter how deep a hole he dug himself, he'd give you the whole speech. And you'd better not point out the obvious.  His creditors would catch up to him. Loan sharks or whatever. He'd wake us in the middle of the night. Off we'd go, again.

Speaker: gary
Dialogue: What would you tell the kids? At your new school? You had to come up with a good story, right?

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: No. I just went deeper into the machine. Preferred being the geek to having to explain. Lying would've been worse.

Speaker: gary
Dialogue: ...Worse?

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: Cause he was a liar. And I hated him.  Guess that's why I'm kind of clueless, even now. Didn't cultivate my conniving side. 'Not sure I even have one.

Speaker: gary
Dialogue: Don't be so hard on yourself. With a brain like yours, you could connive with the best of 'em I bet.

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: He's buying up pretty much everything: cable companies, baby bells, picture libraries, museum rights, film archives... Getting ready for Skywire.

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: What about "60 Minutes."

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: Yeah, they dig stuff like this.  "CBS News has partnered with Outpost Information Systems in a cable news

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: But still, you can't say CBS wouldn't love to break something like --

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: Say there's just one "mole" working there, like Barton at the DOJ. How do we know he's not the guy we've contacted? Or she? Or the guy she works for?

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: Time?

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: It's like a a continuous loop. We can go to some alternative press place that 1,000 people read, get them and us killed. But anything big enough for this is a parent of or a subsidiary to something Gary's got a finger in!

Speaker: homework kid
Dialogue: Shhh.

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: Sorry.

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: Milo?

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: How close are you?

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: He's got 12 satellites up. He's got dishes on top of 21. He's building this --  mega-network for Skywire. Let's use it.

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: We can't just assume they're standing by to receive Skywire 12 months from launch. I'd have to write in an aglet.

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: A what?

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: It's how on-line services push logos they wanna sell you. You don't ask for 'em, they just appear. 'Have to work on it somewhere besides my office or my house. And then the quality of the broadcast wouldn't exactly be digital, that's 12 months away.

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: But they'd still get the idea, right?

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: You'd have to design a graphic interface to make the data pop. Maybe some audio, too. To tie it all in to Gary. How long would that take you?

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: It's a standard GUI. Once I've got a concept, it's maybe three day's work.

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: Gary knows I'm close on Skywire. We have to do this fast.

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: Before they kill somebody else, too.

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: Oh, man. I'd have to get into Gary's house. To get the satellite positions.

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: You mean -- break in?

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: I don't know --

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: And what if the broadcast dishes on top of 21 aren't hot yet? You said the place isn't finished.

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: I'll go look.  They'll just have a few more pictures of me snooping around.

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: Why were you so careless?

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: I thought the worst they would do is fire me. Who knew they took termination so literally?

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: Why were you snooping in my office?

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: Oh.  I liked you. I was checking you out.

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: I told Teddy about you.

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: What'd he say?

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: "A beautiful geek? What're the chances?"

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: I felt guilty. 'Cause I "owed so much" to Alice. But even then I was starting to wonder. Is it so great to be so consumed by this one thing that you let another person do your thinking for you? If you have a lucrative skill, it's all anybody wants from you. You grow older but you don't grow up. You turn into -- into --

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: Gary.

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: Larry used to say how the guys who wrote the first cool operating systems, like the UNIX guys at Berkeley? They just gave it away. They figured it was human knowledge, it belonged to the world, like Shakespeare or aspirin. 'Know what I'm gonna do after we broadcast the incriminating stuff? Air the Skywire code. Then nobody can have a monopoly.

Speaker: alice
Dialogue: Where were you?  You know you can't keep anything from me.

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: Okay, yeah. I did something naughty... There's this amazing Comix store in Seattle.  To tell you the truth, I did it once or twice at Stanford. 'Guess I can't keep anything from you...

Speaker: alice
Dialogue: I won't turn you in.

Speaker: len
Dialogue: Every entry was authorized.

Speaker: shrot
Dialogue: Keep looking.

Speaker: len
Dialogue: What're we looking for?

Speaker: shrot
Dialogue: Any irregularity in the pattern.

Speaker: tv voice
Dialogue: Last years' party-goers pledged over $2 million to the Museum; this year's event promises to raise even more. Lured in part by the chance to see the stunning Boyd house...

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: Look at this.

Speaker: alice
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: Why doesn't he ask us to his party. He's never even met you.

Speaker: alice
Dialogue: He has thousands of employees, Milo --

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: It's for the Museum. He knows you're a painter. If anybody should be invited --

Speaker: alice
Dialogue: Milo --

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: I know you think I'm too attached to him, but still. I am close to Gary. And you're the most meaningful person in my life.  I'm going back to the Comix place, why should I be killing myself.

Speaker: alice
Dialogue: Milo, you --

Speaker: guard
Dialogue: Hey! Get down here!

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: This is a lifesaver. My PC crashed just before finals.

Speaker: sister beatrice
Dialogue: None of us knows how to use it. I'm thinking of taking a course.  May I?

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: Sure.

Speaker: sister beatrice
Dialogue: Forget it.

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: I needed t'see it up close for a graphic. The outpost with a dish on top? I climbed up there to get it right.

Speaker: shrot
Dialogue: Next time you ask.

Speaker: len
Dialogue: 'Might of found something.

Speaker: len
Dialogue: Delbert seems to enter #21 twice. Without leaving the first time.

Speaker: shrot
Dialogue: Let's get him in here.

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: Great. I knocked off the aglet, as soon as I get a passable version of Skywire we're there.

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: The dishes are juiced up, too.

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: Thank God.

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: Milo? Shrot suspects somebody broke into #21. I was in his office when he was reviewing the card readouts.

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: Shrot's not one of them. He's blundering into this on his own.

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: He doesn't know about the Day Care.

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: Hardly anybody does, that's the beauty part. No cameras, the DOJ doesn't bother with it, it's accessed by a tunnel they boast about. You know the best place to hide a leaf?

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: Yeah, that's old, in a tree.

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: Oh.

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: Milo? What if Shrot notices somebody entered the Day Care at four A.M.? And tells them about it?

Speaker: gary
Dialogue: Milo?

Speaker: gary
Dialogue: I'm giving a benefit for the art museum Thursday night. Thought you'd like to bring Alice.

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: That's great! Thanks.

Speaker: gary
Dialogue: 'Sorry about the late notice...

Speaker: desi
Dialogue: "Sorry about the late notice?"

Speaker: shrot
Dialogue: Why did you enter #21 twice?

Speaker: delbert
Dialogue: Huh?

Speaker: delbert
Dialogue: This thing's screwed-up. Look here.  'Shows me going into the Day Care that night. I never been in the Day Care.

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: One window'll be obits I downloaded, based on the scenarios you described. The other windows'll accommodate the surveillance stuff you told me about. The idea is, this works with anything, since we can't edit.

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: Same with the excerpts I'm choosing: they'll play against any of the images you described.

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: Perfect.  How am I gonna get away from the party long enough to --

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: You could always say you have to go the bathroom.

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: That's lame, isn't it?

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: You'll come up with something.

Speaker: alice
Dialogue: They called the house to ask who's your favorite painter.

Speaker: houseman
Dialogue: Sorry, Sir, this part of the residence is restricted.

Speaker: gary
Dialogue: Alice, I'm Gary. This is my wife, Clarissa.  Milo, this is Barry Linder, who's visiting from Hollywood.

Speaker: linder
Dialogue: I hate being the Hollywood guy. It's so limiting. Meet my friend, Ricky.

Speaker: ricky
Dialogue: Hi, guys.

Speaker: gary
Dialogue: Barry's studio's gonna help fill the Skywire pipeline, thought you guys should meet.

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: Cool.

Speaker: society woman
Dialogue: He's a sweetheart. He gave 10,000 PC's to the Library Association.

Speaker: society man
Dialogue: All 10,000 of which will be signed onto his browser, no doubt.

Speaker: society woman
Dialogue: And so what?!
